title: 107_hr1520
content: SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS. The "Eliminate Colorectal Cancer Act of 2001" recognizes colorectal cancer as a significant health issue in the United States, with high mortality rates. Research supports that a healthy lifestyle and regular screenings can reduce the risk of developing this type of cancer. The Screen for Life Campaign aims to educate individuals aged 50 and above about the importance of colorectal cancer screening tests for early detection and prevention. SEC. 2. COVERAGE FOR COLORECTAL CANCER SCREENING. This section amends the Public Health Service Act to include coverage for colorectal cancer screening in group health plans for individuals aged 50 and above. Group health plans and health insurance issuers must cover colorectal cancer screening for individuals aged 50 and over, as well as those under 50 who are at high risk or show symptoms warranting screening. The screening method and frequency should be determined by the treating healthcare provider. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements and not preempt more protective state laws regarding health insurance coverage. Amendments are made to certain sections of the Social Security Act to include additional provisions. Amendments are made to certain sections of the Social Security Act by adding new provisions related to ERISA. Amendments to the Social Security Act include new provisions for ERISA, such as coverage for colorectal cancer screening. Coverage for colorectal cancer screening is mandated for individuals aged 50 and over, as well as those under 50 who are at high risk or show symptoms warranting screening. The screening method and frequency are determined by the healthcare provider in consultation with the individual, as per the group health plan or health insurance issuer's coverage. The text discusses the requirements and modifications related to group health plans under the Social Security Act and Balanced Budget Act of 1997. Amendments are made to sections of the Act, and notice of these requirements must be provided within 60 days of their application. Amendments are made to the table of contents in section 1 of the Act by inserting a new item after section 713. Amendments are made to the table of contents in section 1 of the Act by inserting a new item after section 713, which includes coverage for colorectal cancer screening under individual health insurance. The provisions of section 2707(a) apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market as it does in connection with a group health plan. Health insurance issuers must comply with notice requirements under ERISA. The amendments made by subsection (a) apply to group health plans starting on or after January 1, 2003, with exceptions for plans under collective bargaining agreements. The amendments made by subsection (b) apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market starting on or after January 1, 2003. The Secretaries of Labor and Health and Human Services will coordinate regulations to ensure compliance. The Secretaries are responsible for ensuring coordinated enforcement of regulations to avoid duplication of efforts and prioritize enforcement.
